Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Multi-modal Robot Skins for Adaptive Human-Machine Interfaces
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project will consist of creating higher performance human-machine interfaces, with wide-ranging applications not only in robotics, but also in manufacturing, healthcare, and intelligent consumer products. Increasing human-machine collaboration by adding cost-effective and customizable sensory perception, for instance touch sensing, to future machines will have an impact to their safety when operating around people, and will enhance their usability, productivity, and level of personalization. Consumers at large will benefit from product interfaces that are more intuitive and easier to learn and use. Numerous companies and government labs will also benefit from the commercialization of technology resulting from this project, as it will help retrofit their existing infrastructure with robotic skin patches to make it safer and more productive.

This I-Corps project will undertake commercialization feasibility research for 'Electronic Skin' technologies based on multi-sensory perception of humans interacting physically with machines, through sensing touch pressure, acceleration, temperature and proximity. Using in-house fabricated tactile sensors embedded in flexible substrates, combined with other types of commercial off-the shelf sensors, this project develops modular systems that can be networked and scaled in large numbers. Numerous sensor components are 3D printed, and can be retrofitted onto existing machinery, such as robots, automated production units, appliances in a cost effective manner. Furthermore, the human-machine interface software of the system involves novel learning algorithms that can adapt to user preferences, decrease the task completion time, and the level of expertise required by users. The adaptive software learns to adjust the human-machine parameters in real-time, according to interaction results, and can take into account sensor degradation over time, user fatigue, and other persistent and costly technical challenges that have limited the widespread adoption of this technology in the past.

Institution.Name: University of Louisville Research Foundation Inc

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, an I-Corps team from University of Louisville (UofL) studied the commercialization potential of tactile electronic skin technologies developed at the Next Generation Systems Lab. Electronic skins will enable future robots to perceive the sense of touch, a key ingredient for safe and effective interaction with people and the environment. These devices contain arrays of 3D printed organic polymer sensors embedded in rubber silicones. 

The team was composed of 1) Entrepreneurial Lead (Josh Baptist), 2) PI (Dan Popa, Professor, ECE Department), and 3) Mentor (Daniel Johnsen, MBA). The team was formed in 2016 at the end of a local I-Corps Site project for the Launch It! entrepreneurial program in Louisville, KY. The team participated in the I-Corps training cohort 10 week course based in SF-Bay area. This is the second national I-Corps team formed at UofL, and was instrumental to jump starting our commercialization journey.

During the cohort entrepreneurial training we conducted customer discovery with over 100 companies spanning industrial robotics and automation, consumer electronics and health care. Interviews continued throughout 2017 and the early part of 2018 as we attended several trade shows such as ATX 2017 and CES 2018. As a result of the customer discovery process, we narrowed down the target market for a future eSkin products, and answered important questions related to our value propositions, industrial partnerships, minimum viable products (MVP), and others. Numerous hypotheses were validated and invalidated during customer discovery.  

The team also built a MVP consisting of a retrofit robotic gripper and demonstrated it for potential future partner OEM manufacturers. The project solidified our IP position by completing a PCT application and an Inter-Institutional Agreement with the PI's previous institution in Spring 2018. A new startup company, Next Gen Systems LLC was incorporated in 2017 and funding is being sought to bring this technology to the robotics and automation markets in the near future. 


Last Modified: 05/29/2018
Modified by: Dan O Popa
